title: grown ever more menacing, and which I fear cannot now be lifted
author: peaceful stop! Stop,

elements.text: PART ONE
Wind blowing across a flat plain. A woman of mature years speaks.

Good people of Bortresoye. My people, my dear people. It is with a heavy heart that I speak to you on a matter of the utmost importance to us all. As you know, for far too long a dark cloud has hung over the safety and security of our realm. A cloud which has grown ever more menacing, and which I fear cannot now be lifted by peaceful stop! Stop, stop.
My lady Excelsior is displeased with the text? It isn't too late for final adjustments to be made. A word change here, an altered syntax there. You have only to say and it will be done.
The text is fine, Minister Voss. Hardly poetry, but more than adequate for the occasion. My make-up, on the other hand, is an absolute disaster! Where's my make-up assistant? I want him here now!
If I may be so bold, my lady, you look radiant. Ask my Right Honourable friend the Minister for Peace. Do you not think our lady Excelsior is looking particularly radiant today?
Indeed. My Right Honourable friend the Minister for War speaks the truth.
Don't patronise me, Minister Tralfinial. Nor you, Minister Voss. You're politicians, not beauticians. Now where's the make-up assistant?
Here, my lady.
Well, get on with it, fool. You can see what needs to be done.
I can, my lady?
The wig has slipped a little to one side. The skin at my jawline must be tightened again. Just a notch or two, and be very careful. I don't want it to split in the middle of my broadcast.
No, my lady.
(sotto) Talk to her, Voss. Explain.
(sotto) Yes, yes, I know. (normal) Er, my lady, our people should be given as much warning as possible about the terrible danger they face. Terrible and imminent danger.
I'm aware of that, Minister Voss.
They'll want to prepare themselves, say their goodbyes.
You make it sound like the end of the world approaches, Minister. We're fighting a war which is not yet lost and can still be won. You do believe that, don't you.
Of course.
It would be a great shame if you were to lose faith on the eve of our victory.
There's no question of that happening. Of my losing faith, I mean. Or indeed of not winning the war. Of course we'll win the war.
Good. I'm glad to hear it. Ow! What are you doing, you idiot? Trying to strangle me with my own face?
Sorry, my lady.
What my Right Honourable friend the Minister for War, is trying to say, is that those who have shelters must be allowed one last opportunity to retreat into them before it's too late.
It may soon be too late.
The people are looking to you for guidance and protection, my lady.
You have to let them know that you are safe, that you're still in control.
That you haven't abandoned them.
Oh, choose your words carefully, Minister Tralfinial. I would never abandon my people, you know that. They know that.
They don't know that their government is in a protective bunker deep underground.
And they won't know, unless someone who doesn't value his life tells them.
It certainly won't come from me, my lady.
What about you, my Minister for Peace?
When the war is over, the people will need someone to lead them. Someone they can trust.
My Right Honourable friend the Minister for Peace is referring to you, of course, my lady. We should proceed with the broadcast.
Oh, very well. But it concerns me that I won't be seen at my best. High standards must be maintained, after all. Slackness and indiscipline are not to be tolerated.
In the circumstances, I'm sure our people will understand.
Signal your readiness, my lady.
Oh, get on with it, Minister Voss, otherwise I may change my mind.
Replay the fanfare.

Good people of Bortresoye. My people, my dear people. It is with a heavy heart that I speak to you on a matter of the utmost importance to us all. As you know, for far too long a dark cloud has hung over the safety and security of our realm. A cloud which has grown ever more menacing and which, I fear, cannot now be lifted by peaceful means. Even as I bring you this message, there are forces preparing to launch an attack that represents a genuine threat to our future. I have therefore been left with no alternative but to authorise the use of comparable force, which will drive from our borders all who seek to encroach upon them. I do this in the name of Bortresoye. As in every conflict, there will be casualties. We must expect that. It is the nature of war. But after war there will be peace, and I shall be there to lead you into a bright new future! My people, the hopes and wishes of Excelsior go with you.
Pause.
Your words will give them strength, my lady.
Never mind the words, you fool. My jawline has split. Have that idiot make-up assistant executed!
Feet in heavy boots.
No, my lady. Please.
Keep his skin. At least that will be of some use.
The make-up assistant screams.

Charley? C'Rizz? I told you not to go wandering off. I told you we'd lose each other if we became separated. But you wouldn't listen to me. Now look what's happened. Charley, you must be somewhere. You can't be far away. Charley! Charley! Is that you, C'Rizz? I can see someone. Shout if you can hear my voice. Is that you, Charley? Charley? I know you. I knew you. Katarina? Katarina, the little handmaiden from Troy, years ago. But you died. You're dead. You sacrificed yourself to save others, to save me. It is you, isn't it. It is you. Oh Katarina, I'm so, so sorry. I tried to keep you safe and I let you down. I should have left you where you were. Instead, I gave you hope and watched you die. Please forgive

me. There's someone with you. Who is it? Oh no, no, no, no, no, that's not possible. Adric? No, it's not possible. You and Katarina never met. This is an illusion. It's all in my mind. Or else I'm going mad. Why are you doing this? What is to be gained by it. Why are you tormenting me?
Tormenting you, Doctor?
Yes, you're tormenting me. Why are you tormenting me?
I thought you'd be pleased to see some old friends.
Adric and Katarina are dead, and it gives me no pleasure to see them alive when I know that they are dead. It's an illusion, a figment of my imagination. Take it away.
Life. Death. What's the difference?
A very great difference when you're dead.
How do you know? How can you be sure? Have you ever asked a dead person
Don't play games with me, Kro'Ka. It's bad enough that I'm trapped on this world without your resurrecting images from my past that are calculated to cause pain.
Images?
Spectres, ghosts, call them what you will.
Your dead friends will be disappointed to learn that their appearance causes you such pain.
It's the fact that they're dead which causes me the pain. That I could have done more to help them when they were alive.
Ah. Guilt.

Guilt, yes, to some extent. They travelled with me, they trusted me. Anyway, there's nothing more I can do about it. I can't bring them back any more than you can, Kro'Ka, for all your tricks and mind games.
The power of the Kro'Ka may be greater than you realise. It would be a mistake to underestimate me, Doctor.

The only real power you seem to have is keeping the Tardis hidden. But I'll find it. If I'm forced to cross every zone and search every inch of this planet, I will find it. Maybe you haven't heard. I don't give in easily.
Search where you will. Search long and hard.
I intend to. The Tardis is here somewhere.
Your search will be a longer one still if it isn't.
If it isn't? Another mind game, Kro'Ka? Where's the Tardis!
That would be telling. Patience, Doctor.
You take away my last hope and expect me to be patient? What manner of creature are you?
What manner of creature would you like me to be?
I'm not going to listen to any more of your riddles. Where are Charley and C'Rizz? What have you done with them?
Nothing. Your young friends are waiting for you in the next zone.
Then I would like to join them, with your permission.
They trust you, Doctor. They have faith in you. It's all a question of faith. Life and death, Doctor. Life and death. The end of one journey is the beginning of another. (echoes)
Walking on broken plate glass in a howling wind.
Doctor! Doctor, over here!
Charley?
Over here!
Charley, thank goodness you're all right.
Where have you been? We thought you'd got stuck in the Interzone. We were worried about you.
I got waylaid by the Kro'Ka.
Anything important?
No, not really. Just the usual nonsense. Where's C'Rizz?
Sheltering from the wind. We took turns to look out for you. Come on, this way. Oh, watch your footing. It's all loose.
Sorry I was so long getting here.
Oh, you haven't missed anything. It's dark and cold, mainly, with little patches of sunlight between the clouds. What do you suppose happened to this place?
It must have been a city once. Not so long ago, judging by the rubble. Weeks, maybe days. Nature hasn't started reclaiming it yet.
It's more glass than rubble. These buildings must have been made entirely of glass.
Possibly, but I don't think so. I'm afraid there's another explanation.
Oh, through here, Doctor. Follow me.
Is this it? Doesn't look very safe.
It's better than nothing. Come on.
Charlotte?
It's us.
We were beginning to wonder if you'd left us here on our own, Doctor.
I wouldn't do that. We're a team. We go everywhere together. Isn't that right, Charley?
For better or worse.

On this occasion I think worse. We seem to have arrived in one of the most inhospitable places imaginable. Although something tells me it wasn't always like this. Have you seen any signs of life since you've been here?
None that we recognise.
It was too cold for us to stay outside for long, and we didn't want to go too far away from the Interzone portal in case we missed you.
Quite right. Good thinking. Do you know where we are?
The ground floor of some building, what's left of it. We weren't exactly spoilt for choice. Most of the other buildings have been flattened. Earthquake, do you think?
Not earthquake. Bomb.
Doctor, how many bombs would it take to cause this amount of damage? A hundred? Thousand?
Just the one.
Just the one?

One very powerful, very ugly, bomb. A bomb from which there's little chance of escape for anyone or anything caught within its radius of destruction. A nuclear bomb. An explosive device which taps into the energy source of the planet itself, which can transmute steel and concrete into glass and wipe out whole civilisations at a single stroke.
Thousands of people would live in a city this size.
Tens of thousands, hundreds of thousands, perhaps millions.
Maybe everyone left the city before the bomb exploded, which is why we haven't seen any signs of life.

Let's hope so, but even if they hadn't left the city it's highly unlikely that we'd find signs of life. And if there were some who survived the explosion, then they'd have to survive the fall-out from it, and the nuclear winter you now see outside.
But it's possible.
Yes, it's possible.
Could it have been an accident?
That's also possible. We're guessing. We don't know for sure what happened here. All I'm sure about is that we can't stay. There's probably some lethal radiation.
The Kro'Ka must have sent us here for a reason. He won't let us go until, well, whatever it is has been achieved. We're stuck here, Doctor. We're trapped.
Printer rattling.
It's estimated that the number of casualties worldwide is in the region of sixty million, from a total population of seventy five million. So we live to fight another day.
Haven't you had enough of fighting, Voss? Hasn't all this taught you anything? Aren't you satisfied?
Now the war is over, there's a new peace to be built. Your portfolio, Minister Tralfinial.
The figures my Right Honourable friend the Minister for War presents are incorrect, my lady.
They are estimates.
They are fiction!
Silence. I will not have my ministers bickering with each other. Is that understood?
My Right Honourable friend the Minister for War underestimates the seriousness of what has occured.
And my Right Honourable friend the Minister for Peace is being unduly pessimistic.
Am I? Perhaps my lady Excelsior would like to bring forward her plans for a victory parade.
Oh, thank you for reminding me, Minister Tralfinial. How soon can it be arranged, Minister Voss? I'm anxious to meet my people in their hour of triumph.
Er, there are still a few problems to be resolved, my lady.
Problems? Such as?
Dangerous chemicals were introduced into the atmosphere by our opponents, and haven't yet dissipate enough to be considered safe.
I'll wear a mask.
And hide your face, my lady?
True. What else?

As you can imagine, the emergency services are stretched to capacity. There's a great deal of disruption and confusion. Would it not be more desirable to hold a victory parade when a degree of normality has been restored?

Yes, you're right, Minister Voss. It's important that I'm seen by as many of our people as can be arranged, and if that means having to wait a while longer, then so be it. I shall instruct my seamstress to make further refinements to my victory gown.
Door opens and closes.
Typical of my lady Excelsior is her willingness to turn a negative into a positive.
Excelsior turns into a giggling girl.
Ooo, thank you, Landscar. You should have been a politician, like Ministers Voss and Tralfinial. We were just discussing my victory gown. On or off the shoulder, do you think?
Oh, off, without a doubt. It would be a crime to conceal such elegant shoulders as yours.
Excuse me, This is a private meeting.
So I see. Please, don't let me interrupt.
We won't let you interrupt. How dare you walk in here without authorisation. You have absolutely no right
He has authorisation, Minister Tralfinial. He has mine.

With respect, my lady, this man is not a properly elected member of the government. Therefore he can have no part in the decision-making process. My Right Honourable friend the Minister for War will concur.
My Right Honourable friend the Minister for Peace is correct. I would suggest that we reconvene this meeting at a later date, when our privacy can be guaranteed.
Oh, very well, Ministers. Go.
My lady.
Footsteps.
This is intolerable, Voss. She must be told the truth.
Rather you than me, Tralfinial.
Door opens, printer rattles, door closes.
I seem to have upset your politicians, my dear lady.
That's quite all right, Landscar. They're easily upset. Politicians worry about the smallest things.
The wind's picking up speed, the temperature's dropped. There's hardly any light at all.
We're going to die.
Don't say that, Charley. We're not going to die. Keep telling yourself we are not going to die.
Oh, let's face it, Doctor. I mean, where can we go? What can we do? If we stay here for much longer we'll freeze to death.
And if we don't freeze to death, we'll probably die of this radiation, or worse.

What is the matter with you two? Have you both got some kind of death wish? A serious case of Seasonal Affective Disorder? I've never known you to be so despondent, even when all the odds were stacked against us. I'll get us out of here somehow. Have I ever let you down? Don't answer that.
Oh, sorry, Doctor. It's just, oh, I don't know, it's. There's something about this place. I can't explain it. It's so bleak.
Yes, bleak's the word. All hope abandon ye who enter here.
Doctor, look out!
Crash! Tumble of rubble.
Thanks, C'Rizz. Are you all right, Charley?
I'm all right, yes.
These walls aren't as strong as they look, and they don't look particularly strong.
There's nothing for it, we'll have to take our chances outside, try to find another shelter.
It'll be the same problem wherever we go. I think we should stay here until the wind dies down.

This is a nuclear winter, C'Rizz. The unnatural byproduct of a man-made cataclysm. It could last for decades, centuries. It may never end. So if you're thinking of sitting it out, you'd better make yourself comfortable.
More rubble collapses.
What was that?
The roof, it's caving in!
Get down, both of you. Get down! Now!
Lots of rubble falling.
One slow set of footsteps, a second running to catch up.
Voss.
What is now, Tralfinial? I have work to do.
Falsifying more statistics to impress Excelsior? She may be mad, but she's not stupid. It's pretty obvious to everyone that the war didn't go well.
Obvious to everyone except Excelsior, who prefers to believe that it went extremely well.

Only because you're feeding her misinformation. Tell her the truth. Tell her that it didn't go strictly according to plan. That most of her people are dead. That her beloved Bortresoye is a barren wasteland.
I'm not going to admit that we provoked a war which has wiped out nine tenths of the world's population. Let her work it out for herself. I'll be a safe distance away by then.
Planning to go somewhere, Voss?
As far as possible.
You've seen the reports. The real reports, I mean. There's nowhere to go. We've finally managed to achieve the destruction of our own planet.

When Excelsior realises that she has nothing left to rule, you and I will be the first to be executed. There are enough people still alive in this bunker who support her unconditionally, and who will obey her instructions without question. Ah, we shouldn't be talking like this. We could be overheard.
You're referring to Landscar?
Amongst others.
Who is he, Voss? I don't recall inviting him into the bunker. He isn't my my department.
He certainly isn't in mine. I don't even remember seeing the man before the war started.
They're lying, of course, my dear lady.
Of course, Landscar. It's what politicians do. But the conditions on the surface have been described well enough to me. I think I know what to expect.
I think not, Excelsior.
Oh?
To understand the conditions above ground, you'll need to see them with your own eyes.
I'm advised that there are chemicals in the air. Poisons, pollutants. Are you seriously suggesting that I expose myself to them? Are you quite mad, Landscar?
Not at all, my dear lady. There is another way, and you won't even have to leave this room.
You are mad.
My lady requires a demonstration, but you must open your mind to it.
To what?
Be perfectly still.
W-w-what are you
And silent.
Landscar
Shh!
Sound of howling wind.
What was that?
A breeze, my dear lady. A summer's breeze.
Yes. Yes, I can feel it on my face, growing colder and colder. Much colder. What have you done, Landscar? What have you done?
I have done nothing, my dear lady. You opened your mind to the elements. It is you who have done this. Open your mind still further, dear lady. Be as one with the elements!
I like it, I like it!
Moving rubble with great effort, and coughing.
Oh Doctor, is that you?
It's me, Charlotte.
Oh, C'Rizz. Are you hurt?
I don't think so. It's one of the advantages of being exoskeletal. I can take a bit of a pounding and you don't see the bruises.
Only 'cos they're all on the inside.
Something like that. Where are you? So much dust. Doctor? Doctor?
Save your breath, C'Rizz. I've been calling to him, but he hasn't answered.
He could be buried alive. We've got to get him out. Will you help me, Charlotte? Doctor? Are you in there?
Hey, watch it. You're throwing things on top of me.
Oh sorry, I didn't realise. Sorry, Charlotte. Give me a hand.
I would if I could. You may not have noticed that there's a rather large beam pinning me to the floor. Care to lift it off? I don't seem to be able to. Bit of an awkward angle.
Of course. Sorry.
Stop apologising. It's not your fault. Now, I'll be glad to get the dust out of my eyes.
Scrap of stone being dragged.
Has it gone?
Can't you tell? Here, you can get up now. Give me your arm. Charlotte.
I can't.
Of course you can. Come on.
I can't. I can't move.
What do you mean, you can't move? Can't move what? Can't move your arms? Can't move your legs? What? Can't move what?
Anything. I can't move anything.
Well, try!
I am trying. I can't.
It must be the shock. You're in shock, that's what it is. You'll get the feeling back eventually.
Yes, and eventually the rest of this building is going to collapse on top of us. Oh, you'll have to carry me outside.
It's freezing out there.
Well, at least if I freeze to death, I won't be aware of it. It's one blessing.
I'll get help.
From where?
I don't know, but I'll get help. I won't be long. Don't move.
C'Rizz, come back! C'Rizz! Oh. Don't move, he says. Don't move. In other circumstances that would be quite amusing. Do you hear that, Doctor? Don't move.
Oh, such power, Landscar. What I can do with such power!
A power which is within all living things, my dear lady. If only it could be harnessed. To be truly at one with nature. Think of it. Powerful, ethereal, elemental.
Door opens. Footsteps.
Yes?
Door closes.
My lady.
We were informed of a disturbance in this room.
Minister Tralfinial, Minister Voss, as you can see I'm perfectly well.
Everything is under control.
Has there been a struggle, my lady? Furniture is smashed, papers are strewn across the floor.
You heard what Landscar said, Ministers. Everything is under control. You may leave us.
Very well, my lady. Please be so good as to inform us if there's any further disturbance.
Footsteps.
Lost her temper again.
Something Landscar must have said.
Door opens and closes.
You see, my dear lady? Everything really is under control.
And if it isn't, it will be soon, once I'm able to leave this prison, once I'm reunited with my people, once I'm
No!
Must you keep interrupting me?
Something has changed. Something is different. Life is present now which was absent before.
Hello? Can anyone hear me? Hello? Doctor! C'Rizz! Anyone! Someone help me! Please! Help me!
Sounds like faint muttering voices in the wind.
Hello?
Hello? Hello? Oh, what's that. Just imagining things. Eyes are tired.
The faint voices are here, too.

Hello? I Know you're there. I can hear you. (echoes) Hello? Hello! That wasn't my echo. That wasn't my echo. Hello? I can see you. Wait! No, don't go away. (runs) Please wait. Look, my friends need help. Oh please, can you help us? We need help. Oh, you're our only hope. (stops) Sorry, Charlotte.
Who are you? Please.
Didn't see you there. Didn't hear you. Where did you come from?
Who are you?
C'Rizz. My name's C'Rizz.
C'Rizz.
Look, can you help me, please? My friends are trapped. One's buried, the other's injured. She can't move. Do you understand? She's injured.
Injured.
Yes. You must come with me. Do you have any friends? Is there anyone else who can help? Anyone at all?
No one.
You'll have to do, I suppose. Can you come with me now?
Now.
Please? It's very urgent. They're in a building which could collapse at any moment. I have to get back to them as soon as possible.
Help.
Thank you. I'll show you the way.
C'Rizz? C'Rizz, is that you? Oh, C'Rizz, say something. You're not C'Rizz.
You haven't told me your name. I've told you mine.
C'Rizz.
C'Rizz, that's right. But what's your name? You must have a name.
Requiem.
Requiem. What happened here, Requiem? The Doctor said it was a nuclear bomb.
Bomb.
Were many people killed? Sorry, I shouldn't have asked you that. It was insensitive of me. How long ago did this happen? It must have been quite recent.
Recent.
How recent? A few days? A few weeks?
Recent.
You don't look very strong. How've you managed to survive on your own? Has there been food and water?
Questions.
I'm sorry, I don't mean to annoy you. I need to know what's happened so I can tell my friends, and help them to understand. Maybe find a way to escape.
Escape.
Yes. And you'll come with us. You and anyone else who's still alive.
Alive?
Look, we're nearly there. I'll run on ahead.
Charlotte? Doctor? I told you I wouldn't be long, and guess what? We're not the only ones left. Charlotte? Charlotte, wnere are you? Doctor?
Doctor.
I don't understand. She couldn't move. They've gone, Requiem. Both of them, gone.
The Doctor groans.
You'll be pleased to know that the dressing is only temporary. You were fortunate, Doctor. Your injuries could have been far worse than a minor head wound.
Where are they?
Your companions?
Charley and C'Rizz, yes. Where are they?
Charley is here in the hospital where she's being well looked after.
What about C'Rizz? Where is he?
Still above ground, I'm afraid.
But alive?
As far as I'm aware.
Oh, thank goodness, thank goodness. I don't remember anything after the roof fell in. What happened to Charley? Is she all right?
Her injuries are rather more extensive than yours.
How extensive? I must see her.
She's resting, as you should be.
I must see her now. Ah!
You've had a traumatic experience, Doctor. You might have been killed in the accident.
Those buildings are unsafe because someone decided to drop a nuclear bomb on them. There's nothing accidental about that, I can assure you.
Point taken.
I suppose that Charley and I have to thank you for rescuing us. You seem to know all the details, whatever your name is.
Landscar.
I'm grateful, Landscar.
Gratitude really isn't necessary.
Maybe not, but it makes me feel better.

Your other friend, C'Rizz, had already left before I reached the site of the accident. The collapse. He'd gone in search of some assistance for you, which must mean that he was relatively unharmed. However, we were unable to locate him, and it seemed more important to provide those who'd been injured with urgent medical attention.
Above ground, you said. C'Rizz is still above ground.
That's correct.
Sorry if I seem a bit dim, but where exactly are we?

My lady, Landscar has a blatant disregard for the safety of everyone in this bunker. He has brought two people from the surface who may be heavily contaminated by the poisoned air, and may himself now be contaminated.

I think that unlikely, Minister Tralfinial. Have you considered that what he's done may be construed as an act of kindness towards two of our people? Oh, you really must try to curb your paranoia. It's becoming rather tiresome.

My Right Honourable friend the Minister for Peace is right to be concerned about the risk of contamination, my lady. Moreover, why has Landscar taken such a risk for two people out of so many who must be in need? Who are these people? Who, for that matter, is Landscar?
We know nothing about him. Neither Minister Voss nor I can recall him being
selected for inclusion in the bunker. He isn't an elected member of the government. Who is he? We have the right to know.
Oh, ho, ho, remember who you are, Ministers. You are the servants of the State, but 1, Excelsior, am the State, and you have the right to know nothing! Get out of my sight!
Charley, there's someone to see you.
Hello, Charley.
Doctor. You're a sight for sore eyes. How's the head? Nice bandage.
Never mind my head. I had a lucky escape, which is more than I can say for you.
Try not to tire her, Doctor. She needs plenty of
Plenty of rest. Yes, I know.
Call me if you want anything, Charley.
Thank you, Nurse. Everyone's been so kind.
How do you feel?
Good question. I'm not sure that I do feel. Certainly not from the neck down.
Are you in pain?
No. No pain. No anything, for that matter. It's like my body doesn't belong to me. Where's C'Rizz? Have they found him yet?

No, not yet, but I'm sure he'll be find. You know C'Rizz, he's a survivor. Don't worry about him, just worry about getting back on your feet again. Can't have you lying in bed all day. There's work to be done, places to go, people to meet. Whole new worlds to explore.
I know.

Landscar tells me we're in a security complex about a mile underground. It's one way to avoid bad weather, I suppose. Although I can't really see it replacing the old-fashioned umbrella as a preferred method of protection against the elements. Apart from which, you don't tend to get much in the way of natural light in these places. Doesn't make for healthy living.
I damaged my spine, Doctor.
Spines can be repaired.
No, I mean really damaged. Beyond repair.
Nonsense. Haven't you known me long enough? Nothing is beyond repair.
(laughs) The Tardis?
Yes, all right. All right, almost nothing.
I see it in their eyes, the people who work here, the doctors, the nurses, whenever they look at me. As I see it in yours now.
What? What? What can you see? What are you talking about?
The mixture of pity and understanding. The look which says I want to help, but there's nothing I can do. There's nothing anyone can do.
Charley, you're not making sense.
Oh, don't try to pretend. Be honest with me. Tell me the truth. I'm paralyzed.
Charley, no.
I'm paralyzed, Doctor. I'll never be able to walk again.

parts.searchable_dialogue:
EXCELSIOR: Good people of Bortresoye. My people, my dear people. It is with a heavy heart that I speak to you on a matter of the utmost importance to us all. As you know, for far too long a dark cloud has hung over the safety and security of our realm. A cloud which has grown ever more menacing, and which I fear cannot now be lifted by peaceful stop! Stop, stop.
VOSS: My lady Excelsior is displeased with the text? It isn't too late for final adjustments to be made. A word change here, an altered syntax there. You have only to say and it will be done.
EXCELSIOR: The text is fine, Minister Voss. Hardly poetry, but more than adequate for the occasion. My make-up, on the other hand, is an absolute disaster! Where's my make-up assistant? I want him here now!
VOSS: If I may be so bold, my lady, you look radiant. Ask my Right Honourable friend the Minister for Peace. Do you not think our lady Excelsior is looking particularly radiant today?
TRALFINIAL: Indeed. My Right Honourable friend the Minister for War speaks the truth.

TRALFINIAL: selected for inclusion in the bunker. He isn't an elected member of the government. Who is he? We have the right to know.
EXCELSIOR: Oh, ho, ho, remember who you are, Ministers. You are the servants of the State, but 1, Excelsior, am the State, and you have the right to know nothing! Get out of my sight!
NURSE: Charley, there's someone to see you.
DOCTOR: Hello, Charley.
CHARLEY: Doctor. You're a sight for sore eyes. How's the head? Nice bandage.
DOCTOR: Never mind my head. I had a lucky escape, which is more than I can say for you.
NURSE: Try not to tire her, Doctor. She needs plenty of
DOCTOR: Plenty of rest. Yes, I know.
NURSE: Call me if you want anything, Charley.
CHARLEY: Thank you, Nurse. Everyone's been so kind.
DOCTOR: How do you feel?
CHARLEY: Good question. I'm not sure that I do feel. Certainly not from the neck down.
DOCTOR: Are you in pain?
CHARLEY: No. No pain. No anything, for that matter. It's like my body doesn't belong to me. Where's C'Rizz? Have they found him yet?
DOCTOR: No, not yet, but I'm sure he'll be find. You know C'Rizz, he's a survivor. Don't worry about him, just worry about getting back on your feet again. Can't have you lying in bed all day. There's work to be done, places to go, people to meet. Whole new worlds to explore.
CHARLEY: I know.
DOCTOR: Landscar tells me we're in a security complex about a mile underground. It's one way to avoid bad weather, I suppose. Although I can't really see it replacing the old-fashioned umbrella as a preferred method of protection against the elements. Apart from which, you don't tend to get much in the way of natural light in these places. Doesn't make for healthy living.
CHARLEY: I damaged my spine, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Spines can be repaired.
CHARLEY: No, I mean really damaged. Beyond repair.
DOCTOR: Nonsense. Haven't you known me long enough? Nothing is beyond repair.
CHARLEY: (laughs) The Tardis?
DOCTOR: Yes, all right. All right, almost nothing.
CHARLEY: I see it in their eyes, the people who work here, the doctors, the nurses, whenever they look at me. As I see it in yours now.
DOCTOR: What? What? What can you see? What are you talking about?
CHARLEY: The mixture of pity and understanding. The look which says I want to help, but there's nothing I can do. There's nothing anyone can do.
DOCTOR: Charley, you're not making sense.
CHARLEY: Oh, don't try to pretend. Be honest with me. Tell me the truth. I'm paralyzed.
DOCTOR: Charley, no.
CHARLEY: I'm paralyzed, Doctor. I'll never be able to walk again.

elements.text: PART TWO

[OC]: Good people of Bortresoye, the worst is behind us. We can now make our plans for the future. A future without fear, a future without conflict, a future of peace and prosperity. Rescue operations are underway as I speak. Emergency aid is being provided for those who need it. Food supplies and shelter for those who have lost their homes. Medical treatment for the sick and injured. Thanks to our brave and tireless rescue teams, a great deal of hardship and suffering has been avoided. Everything that can be done is being done to restore normal service as soon as possible. We have survived a dark chapter in our history. No price for freedom is too high, but we must count the cost of war, and do all that we can to prevent such a dark chapter from happening again. My people, the hopes and wishes of Excelsior go with you.
They can't have just disappeared. Charlotte couldn't walk. She couldn't move. And the Doctor was buried under all that debris. Most of the roof, by the look of it. Hey, Requiem, maybe he wasn't dead.
Dead.

He wasn't dead and managed to get out on his own. Or he was helped. You can see where everything's been thrown aside. The Doctor's not that strong. Someone's been here, taken them away. Sorry, Requiem, You've had a wasted journey. Someone got here before us.
I can't accept it, Charley. I simply cannot accept it. Nor should you.
It's not a question of acceptance, Doctor. You can see for yourself. Look at me. I'm not about to jump up from this bed and run a cross-country race.
Not now perhaps, not this minute, but in a few hours, a few days, who knows? You'll have got your strength back and be right as rain. We'll be laughing about this little scare.
I don't think so.
You cannot give up. I won't let you. You have to believe that you're going to get better, that the feeling in the rest of your body will return.
Oh, that I'll pick up my bed and walk? Doctor, for all your amazing skills and talents, you can't perform miracles. There's a limit to what you or anyone can do.
Charley, that's not fair. I've never claimed to be able to perform miracles.
Oh, I'm sorry. I didn't mean it like that.
You're upset, you're frustrated. I understand. All I want to do is make sure you don't give up hope. You have to fight this like you've fought so many things in the past. Fought and won.
My spine isn't magically going to repair itself.
You are being negative again.

I'm not being negative, I'm being realistic. If there are any hospitals left standing on the surface, why did Landscar bring me all the way down here? Why didn't he take me straight to a proper hospital? Wouldn't that have made more sense?
Granted. Whatever else is wrong, your reasoning powers seem fairly intact.
Thank you.
Yes, it would have made more sense, but Landscar may have his own reasons for bringing us here.
An interesting observation.
Hello. I'm the Doctor, this is Charley. You'll forgive her. She can't get up and stand.
I am Minister Voss and this is Minister Tralfinial. Your friend is injured?
Temporarily incapacitated. Thank you for allowing us into your shelter, gentlemen. I doubt that we'd have survived for very long outside.
Door opens.
Excuse me, Ministers. Can I help you?
We wish to speak to your new patients.
I'll let you know as soon as they're ready to be interviewed.
We wish to speak to them now. Please leave us.
I'm sure you have other tasks to perform.
This is a hospital, Ministers, not a place of interrogation.
You exceed your authority. Leave us!
We'll be all right, nurse. A little chat with the Ministers can't do any harm.
Very well, but it's most irregular.
Footsteps recede, door closes.
Now, let's see. Yes, your readings indicate a minimal exposure to contamination. Far below anything we expect from survivors.
Can you account for this anomaly, Doctor?
I can certainly try.
(sotto) Doctor.
(sotto) Charley, they'll either believe me or they won't. There's clearly no point in trying to pull the wool over their eyes. They're intelligent people.
Well?
Charley and I are not survivors. We were sent here as part of a mission. A test, if you like. We arrived only a few hours ago, and, well, that's about it.
You were sent on a mission?
A sort of mission, yes.
You're spies.
No!
Sent here by our opponents.
No, we're not spies, we're innocent civilians caught up in something we don't understand.
We didn't ask to be brought down into your bunker. We had no idea where Landscar was taking us. And a pretty useless spy I'd make in this condition.
Who sent you?
Not your opponents, whoever they are. We were sent by the Interzone guardian, a rather unpleasant fellow called Kro'Ka. Ring any bells? No, I didn't think it would.
You're trying to confuse us.
I'm trying to explain. I could have lied to you. I could have told you we'd been hiding in another shelter.
There were no other shelters. None that would have withstood the blast.
Precisely. Oh. Anyway, the point is that we're here, and we're grateful. But if you'd rather we went back outside, then so be it.
Thank you, Doctor. That is an option we're considering.
Thunder mixed in with the howling wind.
Sounds like a storm's on its way, Requiem. How much further do we have to go?
Not much further. Almost there.
Hey, that was a whole sentence. You spoke a whole sentence, not just one or two words. What's different? What's changed?
I'm comfortable with you, C'Rizz. You're a good man. You care for others. People should care.

I er, hope you don't mind taking me to where you live. Until I find the Doctor and Charlotte, I've nowhere else to go. They could be miles away and in the opposite direction. Oh, they could be anywhere. And I think it's about to rain. Oh, we're going to get wet if we don't ow! That burnt! The rain's burning my skin. Ah! Oh, can't you feel it? Come on, Requiem, run faster. Come on!
Sounds of rushing water.
How curious.
My dear lady?

See this, Landscar? Water drips from my fingertips. No, not water. Acid. Drip. Drip, drip. Oh, see how the surface of this table reacts to each drop. Each tiny drop leaving its mark. And then the (sniffs) acrid smell of burning wood. Faint, but detectable and oh, oh so delicious.

You are truly in tune with the elements, my dear lady. Every fibre of your being resonates with the power of all that is around you. Your mind reaches beyond this fragile shelter to solid rock, to soil, to water, to fire with burns at the very heart of this world, sweeping upwards again through layer after layer after layer of history, emerging at last into the light. The searing, blinding, terrible light. It rains, and your body can sense it, can feel it caressing your skin.
Or there is another source of water. Closer, stronger. Ah! Much stronger.
Yes, yes, my lady. A subterranean river flows nearby. You're right. You are right. But the torrent threatens to overwhelm us. We are as nothing against such a force of nature. Nothing!
The sound of water stops.
You speak of threats, Landscar, and yet you venture to the surface without my permission. You bring back survivors who may be contaminated. What say you to that?
They are not contaminated, my lady. Nor are they survivors in your meaning of the word. They are travellers. They do not belong here.
Travellers? From where?
From other worlds, my lady.
Oh nonsense, Landscar. You're a fool if you believe such a thing. These people have been filling your head with stupid lies. Their ordeal has demented them.
This information has not come from their mouths.
Then how did you come by it? They must have told you.
I know it to be the truth, my lady. They should not be here. They don't belong here.
Your cryptic remarks are beginning to annoy me, Landscar. Be very careful that they don't annoy me too much. The fact that you have my ear doesn't mean that you can't be executed.
Yours to command, my lady Excelsior.
Hmm. Tell me about the mood of jubilation on the surface. Tell me that my people are waiting anxiously to see me again.
Oh, indeed. The people of Bortresoye are looking forward to being reunited
with you. It will be a great moment in the history of the world.

I must start preparing myself. There are many things to be done. I need a new make-up assistant. My victory gown is to be made ready for a final fitting. And you'll be there, Landscar, at my side. Together we shall watch the new dawn.
As you say, my lady. The new dawn.
Footsteps.
This place is huge, Requiem. It's vast. Is this where you live?
It's where I live now. It's where I worked. My home was destroyed when the light came.
The light? Oh, you mean the bomb.

We saw only the light. The rest was darkness. This is the Archive, where all our records were kept. The history of my people. Everything was here. Much of it has been destroyed. The light penetrated even to this great depth.
We must be about fifty feet underground.
It wasn't enough. We sought shelter down here, thinking it would be adequate protection, Many still perished.
How many of you survived?
Some. For a while. But there was sickness and hunger. It was difficult.

Hmm. It was like that back home, after the Kromon attacked. Most of my family and friends died then, so I know what it's like. Here look, look at this. I've worn it around my neck for ages. It's called a moonstone. It was given to me by my father as a wedding gift He gave me this half and kept the other for himself. A way of, well, Keeping us together, even though we ended up far apart. When I look at this, I can remember them all. All their faces. Well, while we were under the Kromon's power, thinking of them all just kept me going, kept me alive. What about you, Requiem? How have you managed to stay alive?
I don't know. Some kind of inner strength, some energy pushes me on, but I can't describe it and I can't explain it. I hope to learn the truth one day.
I'm sorry, Requiem, I have to ask. Why did all this happen? Why so much death and destruction? Who allowed it to happen?

Our government was weak, frightened. When the risk of an attack was imminent, it was we who struck first. Retaliation by other governments was immediate and total. Nothing could be done to prevent the complete destruction of Bortresoye. I remember the light, and then regaining consciousness to find the Archive as you see it now. Only much later did I venture to the surface and discover the terrible extent of our folly.
Your government's folly.

We've always been at war, throughout history. Each successive government has tried to negotiate a lasting peace, only to end up causing another war. Little by little we have been brought to our knees.
When you say we, you mean the city.

I mean Bortresoye. The whole world. The whole of Bortresoye has always been at war. Everyone. What surprises me is that we've lasted as long as we have, especially since natural resources were exhausted long ago, and we're the only species left on the planet.
You can't be. There must be thousands of different species. Millions. Well, everything from the smallest organism to the largest animal.
All eradicated, C'Rizz, one after the other. Through excessive harvesting,
through biological warfare, through scientific experimentation, the end result was the same. Extinction.
Rumble and crash.
What was that?
The world has become increasingly unstable, C'Rizz. By our actions, we've dealt it the final blow.
Doctor, please tell us how you arrived on Bortresoye.
That's a bit difficult, I'm afraid.
Why?
I don't know how we got here. I'm not privy to that information.
Your mode of transport, what was it?
We didn't have one.
We just sort of arrived.
Through the Interzone.
Interzone?
Yes, Interzone. I told you it would be difficult to explain.
How were you expected to return to your own people?
We weren't. And they're not our own people.
There's no way back, you see. It's a one way ticket.
Rumble.
Was that an earthquake, Doctor?
Yes. And that's a little worrying when you're inside a concrete box a mile underground. Excuse me, Ministers, does that tend to happen regularly around here?
There is some seismic activity, yes.

I see. Look, I think we should be getting out of here. I'm sure I don't need to remind you that we're surrounded on all sides by millions of tons of shifting rock. Can't we discuss the Interzone at a later date?
You're not going anywhere, Doctor.
Least of all without us.
Voss, are you mad, telling two strangers that you're looking to escape?
Actually, he didn't exactly say that. He simply made it clear that we won't be allowed to leave this bunker unaccompanied.
That's not how it sounded.

Tralfinial, listen to me. There's a small possibility that the Doctor and his friend are telling the truth. They may have access to technology which is far more advanced than anything we have here. Isn't that worth investigating?
I don't intend to abandon my people, Voss.
What people? What people? There's no one left, apart from a handful of survivors on the surface who won't live long.
What about everyone down here? What about your colleagues, your friends, your leader?
I have no friends, My colleagues can take care of themselves. And as for our beloved leader
You're just as guilty of what's happened as the rest of us. You're not going to be able to walk away from it. There's the future to think about now.
No, don't you understand? It's finished. We have no future.
Door opens. Running footsteps.
Excelsior, please. My patients
Are my subjects, nurse, and therefore I can disturb them as and when I see fit. Now, you. Yes, you there. You're the first to see it. How do I look?
I beg your pardon?

My victory gown. This is how the rest of our people will see me. It isn't finished yet, of course. There are a few little refinements to be added, but overall, what do you think? And be honest. You're in something of a privileged position. Not everyone will get a sneak preview. I'm anxious to create just the right effect.
I don't really know what to say. You, Charley, you're more the frocks department than I am.
Doctor, I can't see a thing. Prop me up a bit.
That may not be wise. We don't want to risk damaging your spine even more.
Please. I feel like a lemon just lying here.
All right. Let me put a pillow behind your head. There. Better?
Mmm. Much better, thanks.
Well?

Er, turn around. Well, the hem could be dropped about an inch, and you need a belt to pull the waist in. I mean, not too much. Something loose. A cord you can tie, perhaps, made in the same fabric? Otherwise, yes, very nice. Very regal.
You have good taste, young lady. What's your name?
Charlotte.
Charlotte.
My friends call me Charley.
And er, you are?
Call me Doctor.
Doctor. I, of course, need no introduction.
Well, we are new here, so an introduction may be helpful.
(nervous) The Doctor and Charley are still er, disorientated from their experiences, Excelsior.
I see.
It'll pass.
I hope so. I am your leader!
Leader?
Excelsior. And please don't stand on ceremony. After all, you're the war heroes.
Excelsior! Of course. Charley, didn't I say we could expect a visit from the leader?
You did.
Good for morale.
It's unfortunate that you were injured, Charley.
To say the least.
Many have lost their lives.
(sotto) To say the least.
We owe them a great debt of gratitude in securing for us the freedoms that we too often take for granted. Their sacrifice makes it possible for the rest of us to lead our
normal daily lives unhindered by the fear of oppression, or by the want of basic necessities. Thanks to those heroes, most of us still have our homes, our dignity, our pride. Were it not for their
Excuse me, Excelsior, leader.
Yes?
When was this speech written?
Speech? What speech?
I'm starting to get the uncomfortable impression that it was a while ago. Possibly before the bomb dropped?
Bomb? What bomb?
Oh dear.
You don't know? You must know.
Know what?
Life on the surface, or rather, the lack of it. What do you know about what's been happening above ground?
My Ministers have kept me informed.
Indeed we have, Excelsior.
Always.
You see? I know all there is to know. Ministers, leave us. I wish to interview these two brave subjects alone.
But surely
Come, Tralfinial. Now!
Door opens and closes.
And what exactly have your Ministers told you?

They've exaggerated certain things, of course. Each of them hopes to increase his department's budget in the new financial period. There's nothing unusual in that. My Minister for War will ask for more money from the Fighting Fund. My Minister for Peace will ask for more money from the Benevolent Fund. Public taxes will increase accordingly, as they always do after a crisis. There'll be a vote of no confidence in the government, another election, I'll win by a landslide majority.
In the absence of any effective opposition.
If you wish to see it that way, yes.
Excelsior, there's something else you should know, and I hate being the one who has to tell you.
Go on.
Things aren't quite as you're expecting them to be up there.
Sorry, Charley, I don't follow.
Let's just say that your victory gown may not get much of an audience.
Still don't follow.
Just tell her, Doctor.
Yes, I'm coming to it. Don't rush me.
They're dead, Excelsior. They're all dead. Every last one of them. Dead.
Who?
Who do you think?
What Charley is trying to say is that things could have gone better.
They could hardly have gone worse.
We were at war, Doctor. Casualties are inevitable.
True, Nurse, but there's usually a limit set on it. Not the entire population. That's otherwise known as genocide. Something that most civilised societies would frown upon.

Oh, you're wrong. Many of our people have survived. Evidently your experiences were more traumatic than we first imagined. The danger is that others may start to believe you. I can't allow that to happen. Such talk could spread like a disease. Bad for morale.
So what are you going to do, have us silenced?
If necessary, yes.
Door opens.
My lady, we have an emergency!
Well?
The outer wall has been breached.
Charley, the tremors.
Take me to it.
This way.
I'll come with you.
Doctor!
Please, what's happening?
Oh, get out of my way, Nurse.
Stay with Charley, Nurse. I won't be long.
Oh, that's what C'Rizz said, and I haven't seen him since.
[OC]: As in every conflict, there will be casualties. We must expect that. It is the nature of war. But after war there will be peace. And I shall
This was the final broadcast before the war started.
[OC]: Bright new future. My people, the hopes and wishes of Excelsior go with you.
Who is Excelsior?
Our democratically elected leader. The head of the government. The decision maker.
The one who made all the wrong decisions, then.
Don't judge us too harshly, C'Rizz. We have learnt the hardest lesson of all.
Your governments have been ignoring the lessons for too long. Well, now it's too late. There's nothing left to govern.

The pity of it is that no one else will ever hear of our mistakes, to take heed of them. The money that was to have been spent on space exploration was rechanneled into building yet more weapons. It will all have been in vain. We built weapons to defend our homeland. Those same weapons have destroyed us.
Whispering voices.
Requiem, if you've been alone down here, then who is that?
A friend.
And that? And those? Requiem, how many of you are there?
The number is growing.
You've lied to me. You said you were on your own.
I said no such thing. That was your assumption.
Why didn't you tell me? This is great. This means there is hope for the future.
Oh, you think so?
Yes, of course. It hasn't all been in vain. Well, if you survived, there may be others. Enough to build a community and start again, free of your stupid government.
(sighs) We'll never be free. Not while Excelsior lives.
Oh, come on. The bomb that destroyed your homes must have destroyed hers, unless she's somehow invincible.
Not invincible, but according to secret government papers, well protected in her security shelter, along with the rest of them.
Interesting. Well, a place like that would have food and medical supplies which your people need. Where is this security shelter?
About three miles away.
Good. Not far.
And one mile down.
Oh.
The breach is behind a section of wall in corridor twelve, my lady. Monitors show the pressure is increasing in that same area.
Thank you, Minister Voss. Will the inner wall contain it?
Not indefinitely. Not at all if there's another seismic disturbance, even a minor one.
Distant rumble.
Like that, you mean?
Minister Tralfinial, this security installation was built to withstand far worse.
It has withstood far worse, my lady, but the structure has been weakened by constant tremors, and won't stand up to much more. We should evacuate these lower levels as a precaution.
If and when I give the order.
There are more than a hundred people in this shelter. They must be given sufficient warning to prepare for an emergency.
Are you questioning my authority, Minister?
No, my lady.
Then be silent! I have the situation under control.
Landscar, I take it that there's something rather powerful and potentially dangerous behind the wall of corridor twelve.
Yes, Doctor. A subterranean river flows closest to us at that point, and could break through. There is a high risk of flooding.
You don't seem particularly bothered about that. You'll drown with the rest of us.
All living things must die.
True, but we don't have to stand here waiting for it to happen. There must be something you can do.
We can move to ground level and seal off this part of the shelter, with Excelsior's permission.
Having given the matter careful consideration, I've decided that er, we should move to ground level and seal off this part of the shelter. Minister Voss? You'll lead the way.
Monitors show that the inner wall has fractured, my lady. Water is pouring into corridor twelve.
We'll drown!
Charley. I must get Charley!
Make for the end of corridor sixteen, Doctor. A lift will take you to the ground level.
Corridor sixteen. Thank you, Minister Voss. Good luck.
This way, my lady.
They'll have to let us in when we get there, Requiem. They can't leave us outside to die.
Why not? They allowed the war to be fought. They allowed the light to destroy everything. What do they care about a handful of survivors?
Come on, there's fifty people following us, or maybe more. It's hardly a handful. Still, will there be room for everyone in the shelter?
Nurse, can you help me with Charley?
Of course.
We need to move her to ground level without causing any more damage to her spine. Is that possible?
Doctor, what's going on?
The shelter's flooding. We have to get out of here.
Charley's bed comes free of the base as a stretcher.
We have to get to the end of corridor sixteen as quickly as we can.
It isn't far.
Right, ready Nurse?
Ready when you are.
And lift. That's it. You all right, Charley?
I still can't feel anything.
It's probably just as well.
I'll lead the way, Doctor.
Thank you.
Is that water I can hear?
Yes, we're walking through about two inches of it. Tell me if you feel cold.
In the circumstances, I'll worry about that later.
We've been hiding down here in the darkness, pretending that everything would be all right. Fooling ourselves.
Where there's life there's hope.
What hope, Doctor? What life? We've destroyed our world. What is there to go back to now? Why are we even trying to save ourselves?
Because.
Because what?
Just because. Keep going. Corridor sixteen. Corridor sixteen!
Straight ahead. Listen.
Loud rushing water.
Let's just hope that's coming from behind us, not from in front.
This is it, Doctor. Corridor sixteen.
[OC]: Doctor!
Minister Voss.
Into this lift, quickly, all of you.
It's getting very close, Doctor.
I'm aware of that, Charley. Try not to panic.
Let me take that from you, Nurse.
Of course, Minister.
Thank you. Charley, are you all right?
Doctor, get in!
Nurse!
The Nurse screams. The lift doors close and it starts to clank upwards.
What about the Nurse?
The water's taken her, Doctor. There's nothing we can do for her now. We have to close the doors.
No! No, we have to save her.
It's too late. We're heading for ground level.
You can't let her die! Please, Doctor.
She's already dead.
Charley, you have to understand. The whole area is flooded. We can't go back down there.
The Nurse helped carry me and we let her die. You should have taken her and left me there. What use am I like this, a vegetable?
You're not a vegetable, you're a human being. You have just as much right to live as any other creature.
Human being.
Oh dear. It's a figure of speech, Minister.
You really are travellers. Not from another land, but from another world.
The lower levels must be sealed, my lady, without delay.
We'll wait for Minister Voss to return, Minister Tralfinial. I need my seamstress. As it is, this gown has been ruined by the water. The rest of my wardrobe has been destroyed!
The lift is arriving, my lady.
Very well. The lower levels can now be sealed. Nothing and no one must be able to get in or out of them. See to it.
Lift doors open, sloshing water.
You're safe, Charley.
I still think you should send the lift back. Send it back empty. You don't have to go back down there with it.
Where's my seamstress?
Dead, my lady. Drowned, along with everyone else who was down there. I couldn't risk waiting any longer.
You had the temerity to come back without my seamstress, Minister? It would have been better if you'd stayed down there yourself.
Will you just for one moment stop thinking about your ridiculous victory gown?
What did you say, Minister Voss? I'll have you executed for that!
Executed by whom, my lady? Apart from you, there's Minister Tralfinial, the Doctor and Charley.
I'll execute you myself, Minister. Tralfinial, hand me your gun.
What are you doing? Let me get this straight. We are all that's left of more than a hundred people who were on the lower levels.
That's correct.
Those poor people.

Five people out of more than a hundred, and you're talking about executions? Doesn't that strike you as being a little precipitate, a bit rash, not to say insane? Fine, go ahead. What's one more death when you've already seen so many?
Perhaps I should execute you, Doctor.
No! My lady.
Minister Voss disagrees.

Surely you can afford to be magnanimous in victory, Excelsior? Isn't that how your people would wish to see you? As their benevolent ruler. All forgiving and so on. The Doctor and I, we are your people.

I like you, Charley. Very well. A stay of execution for Minister Voss and for the Doctor, for now. Ministers, I have much to prepare before meeting my people on the surface. You will arrange temporary chamber for me on this level.
Yes, my lady.
Doctor, she's completely mad.
You noticed.
All those people have died, more than a hundred people, and her only concern is what she's wearing.
Added to the millions who must have died in the war, it's no wonder she's gone mad.
Don't make excuses for her. She has to accept at least some responsibility for what's happened.
Too many people have pandered to her whim for too long. They've kept any bad or distressing news from her and given her only good news. Whatever it takes to keep her happy.
She can't be that blind, Doctor.
Delusional is a better description. A way of dealing with the enormity of what's taken place. It's easier to block it out, pretend it isn't true.

How can you block out an entire war? How can you block out death and destruction on such a massive scale? There must be something in her head, some little spark of acknowledgment that dropping bombs on people is wrong. That war of any sort is wrong.

Not everyone would agree with that sentiment, Charley, but I take your point. What you have to understand is that Excelsior is probably traumatised by recent events, that her reaction is natural and involuntary.
Or she's bluffing.
Or she's bluffing.
Rasping noise.
What's that?
Some sort of alarm, I think.
Doctor, it's the perimeter sensors outside the shelter. They're calibrated to detect lifeforms. Something's out there. It's either curious or it's trying to get in.
Don't open the door, Voss. Whatever you do, don't open the door.
I'll check the monitor first, Tralfinial. Don't worry. If it looks in any way threatening or dangerous, it stays outside. I'm not a complete idiot, you know.
The image resolution isn't very good. It must be the storm affecting it.
What can you see?
I'll scan the area. Try to sharpen the image. I can see something. Someone.
Is anyone there? Hello? Can you hear me?
I saw the lens move. They are watching us, C'Rizz. You must keep shouting.
Maybe they can't hear me.
But they can see you.
What sort of creature is that?
It's C'Rizz!
Oh, Doctor, he's alive.
Apparently.
I'll bring up the sound.
And he's not a creature, he's a Eutermesan.
What?
He's with me. He's a friend. He can be trusted.
C'RIZZ [OC]: Can anyone hear me? Hello?
Can he hear us?
He can now.
C'Rizz, can you hear me?
C'RIZZ [OC]: Doctor? Is that you?
Yes. We're going to let you in.
You can't.
He'll freeze out there. You have to let him in.
We don't have to do anything of the sort, Doctor. We're only taking your word for it that he can be trusted.
Please. He won't harm you.
C'RIZZ [OC]: I have some friends with me.
He isn't alone, Voss.
They must be survivors.
How many friends, C'Rizz?
C'RIZZ [OC]: About fifty.
Fifty? Think of the contamination.
Fifty survivors of the war, Minister. Fifty people who need protection from the storm. You must let them in.
I'm opening the doors.
Think what you're doing, Voss.
The Doctor's right. We can't leave them outside to die.
Let them in, and we could die.
Well, that's a risk I'm prepared to take. Doors opening.
I'll shoot to kill any intruder who threatens us.
No, lower your weapon.
I'm warning you. If necessary, I'll kill them all.
C'Rizz!
Doctor. Charlotte.
Where are the others? You said there were about fifty of them.
Can't you count? Look at them.
Yes, I can count, but I can only count one, and that's you.
Open your eyes, Doctor.
There's no one with you, C'Rizz. You're alone.

parts.searchable_dialogue:
EXCELSIOR: [OC]: Good people of Bortresoye, the worst is behind us. We can now make our plans for the future. A future without fear, a future without conflict, a future of peace and prosperity. Rescue operations are underway as I speak. Emergency aid is being provided for those who need it. Food supplies and shelter for those who have lost their homes. Medical treatment for the sick and injured. Thanks to our brave and tireless rescue teams, a great deal of hardship and suffering has been avoided. Everything that can be done is being done to restore normal service as soon as possible. We have survived a dark chapter in our history. No price for freedom is too high, but we must count the cost of war, and do all that we can to prevent such a dark chapter from happening again. My people, the hopes and wishes of Excelsior go with you.
C'RIZZ: They can't have just disappeared. Charlotte couldn't walk. She couldn't move. And the Doctor was buried under all that debris. Most of the roof, by the look of it. Hey, Requiem, maybe he wasn't dead.
REQUIEM: Dead.
C'RIZZ: He wasn't dead and managed to get out on his own. Or he was helped. You can see where everything's been thrown aside. The Doctor's not that strong. Someone's been here, taken them away. Sorry, Requiem, You've had a wasted journey. Someone got here before us.
DOCTOR: I can't accept it, Charley. I simply cannot accept it. Nor should you.
CHARLEY: It's not a question of acceptance, Doctor. You can see for yourself. Look at me. I'm not about to jump up from this bed and run a cross-country race.
DOCTOR: Not now perhaps, not this minute, but in a few hours, a few days, who knows? You'll have got your strength back and be right as rain. We'll be laughing about this little scare.
CHARLEY: I don't think so.
DOCTOR: You cannot give up. I won't let you. You have to believe that you're going to get better, that the feeling in the rest of your body will return.
CHARLEY: Oh, that I'll pick up my bed and walk? Doctor, for all your amazing skills and talents, you can't perform miracles. There's a limit to what you or anyone can do.
DOCTOR: Charley, that's not fair. I've never claimed to be able to perform miracles.
CHARLEY: Oh, I'm sorry. I didn't mean it like that.
DOCTOR: You're upset, you're frustrated. I understand. All I want to do is make sure you don't give up hope. You have to fight this like you've fought so many things in the past. Fought and won.
CHARLEY: My spine isn't magically going to repair itself.
DOCTOR: You are being negative again.
CHARLEY: I'm not being negative, I'm being realistic. If there are any hospitals left standing on the surface, why did Landscar bring me all the way down here? Why didn't he take me straight to a proper hospital? Wouldn't that have made more sense?
DOCTOR: Granted. Whatever else is wrong, your reasoning powers seem fairly intact.
CHARLEY: Thank you.
DOCTOR: Yes, it would have made more sense, but Landscar may have his own reasons for bringing us here.
VOSS: An interesting observation.
DOCTOR: Hello. I'm the Doctor, this is Charley. You'll forgive her. She can't get up and stand.
VOSS: I am Minister Voss and this is Minister Tralfinial. Your friend is injured?
DOCTOR: Temporarily incapacitated. Thank you for allowing us into your shelter, gentlemen. I doubt that we'd have survived for very long outside.
NURSE: Excuse me, Ministers. Can I help you?
VOSS: We wish to speak to your new patients.
NURSE: I'll let you know as soon as they're ready to be interviewed.
VOSS: We wish to speak to them now. Please leave us.
TRALFINIAL: I'm sure you have other tasks to perform.
NURSE: This is a hospital, Ministers, not a place of interrogation.
VOSS: You exceed your authority. Leave us!
DOCTOR: We'll be all right, nurse. A little chat with the Ministers can't do any harm.
NURSE: Very well, but it's most irregular.
TRALFINIAL: Now, let's see. Yes, your readings indicate a minimal exposure to contamination. Far below anything we expect from survivors.
VOSS: Can you account for this anomaly, Doctor?
DOCTOR: I can certainly try.
CHARLEY: (sotto) Doctor.
DOCTOR: (sotto) Charley, they'll either believe me or they won't. There's clearly no point in trying to pull the wool over their eyes. They're intelligent people.
TRALFINIAL: Well?
DOCTOR: Charley and I are not survivors. We were sent here as part of a mission. A test, if you like. We arrived only a few hours ago, and, well, that's about it.
TRALFINIAL: You were sent on a mission?
DOCTOR: A sort of mission, yes.
VOSS: You're spies.
DOCTOR: No!
VOSS: Sent here by our opponents.
DOCTOR: No, we're not spies, we're innocent civilians caught up in something we don't understand.
CHARLEY: We didn't ask to be brought down into your bunker. We had no idea where Landscar was taking us. And a pretty useless spy I'd make in this condition.
TRALFINIAL: Who sent you?
DOCTOR: Not your opponents, whoever they are. We were sent by the Interzone guardian, a rather unpleasant fellow called Kro'Ka. Ring any bells? No, I didn't think it would.
TRALFINIAL: You're trying to confuse us.
DOCTOR: I'm trying to explain. I could have lied to you. I could have told you we'd been hiding in another shelter.
VOSS: There were no other shelters. None that would have withstood the blast.
DOCTOR: Precisely. Oh. Anyway, the point is that we're here, and we're grateful. But if you'd rather we went back outside, then so be it.
VOSS: Thank you, Doctor. That is an option we're considering.
C'RIZZ: Sounds like a storm's on its way, Requiem. How much further do we have to go?
REQUIEM: Not much further. Almost there.
C'RIZZ: Hey, that was a whole sentence. You spoke a whole sentence, not just one or two words. What's different? What's changed?
REQUIEM: I'm comfortable with you, C'Rizz. You're a good man. You care for others. People should care.
C'RIZZ: I er, hope you don't mind taking me to where you live. Until I find the Doctor and Charlotte, I've nowhere else to go. They could be miles away and in the opposite direction. Oh, they could be anywhere. And I think it's about to rain. Oh, we're going to get wet if we don't ow! That burnt! The rain's burning my skin. Ah! Oh, can't you feel it? Come on, Requiem, run faster. Come on!
EXCELSIOR: How curious.
LANDSCAR: My dear lady?
EXCELSIOR: See this, Landscar? Water drips from my fingertips. No, not water. Acid. Drip. Drip, drip. Oh, see how the surface of this table reacts to each drop. Each tiny drop leaving its mark. And then the (sniffs) acrid smell of burning wood. Faint, but detectable and oh, oh so delicious.
LANDSCAR: You are truly in tune with the elements, my dear lady. Every fibre of your being resonates with the power of all that is around you. Your mind reaches beyond this fragile shelter to solid rock, to soil, to water, to fire with burns at the very heart of this world, sweeping upwards again through layer after layer after layer of history, emerging at last into the light. The searing, blinding, terrible light. It rains, and your body can sense it, can feel it caressing your skin.
EXCELSIOR: Or there is another source of water. Closer, stronger. Ah! Much stronger.
LANDSCAR: Yes, yes, my lady. A subterranean river flows nearby. You're right. You are right. But the torrent threatens to overwhelm us. We are as nothing against such a force of nature. Nothing!
EXCELSIOR: You speak of threats, Landscar, and yet you venture to the surface without my permission. You bring back survivors who may be contaminated. What say you to that?
LANDSCAR: They are not contaminated, my lady. Nor are they survivors in your meaning of the word. They are travellers. They do not belong here.
EXCELSIOR: Travellers? From where?
LANDSCAR: From other worlds, my lady.
EXCELSIOR: Oh nonsense, Landscar. You're a fool if you believe such a thing. These people have been filling your head with stupid lies. Their ordeal has demented them.
LANDSCAR: This information has not come from their mouths.
EXCELSIOR: Then how did you come by it? They must have told you.
LANDSCAR: I know it to be the truth, my lady. They should not be here. They don't belong here.
EXCELSIOR: Your cryptic remarks are beginning to annoy me, Landscar. Be very careful that they don't annoy me too much. The fact that you have my ear doesn't mean that you can't be executed.
LANDSCAR: Yours to command, my lady Excelsior.
EXCELSIOR: Hmm. Tell me about the mood of jubilation on the surface. Tell me that my people are waiting anxiously to see me again.
LANDSCAR: Oh, indeed. The people of Bortresoye are looking forward to being reunited
LANDSCAR: with you. It will be a great moment in the history of the world.
EXCELSIOR: I must start preparing myself. There are many things to be done. I need a new make-up assistant. My victory gown is to be made ready for a final fitting. And you'll be there, Landscar, at my side. Together we shall watch the new dawn.
LANDSCAR: As you say, my lady. The new dawn.
C'RIZZ: This place is huge, Requiem. It's vast. Is this where you live?
REQUIEM: It's where I live now. It's where I worked. My home was destroyed when the light came.
C'RIZZ: The light? Oh, you mean the bomb.
REQUIEM: We saw only the light. The rest was darkness. This is the Archive, where all our records were kept. The history of my people. Everything was here. Much of it has been destroyed. The light penetrated even to this great depth.
C'RIZZ: We must be about fifty feet underground.
REQUIEM: It wasn't enough. We sought shelter down here, thinking it would be adequate protection, Many still perished.
C'RIZZ: How many of you survived?
REQUIEM: Some. For a while. But there was sickness and hunger. It was difficult.
C'RIZZ: Hmm. It was like that back home, after the Kromon attacked. Most of my family and friends died then, so I know what it's like. Here look, look at this. I've worn it around my neck for ages. It's called a moonstone. It was given to me by my father as a wedding gift He gave me this half and kept the other for himself. A way of, well, Keeping us together, even though we ended up far apart. When I look at this, I can remember them all. All their faces. Well, while we were under the Kromon's power, thinking of them all just kept me going, kept me alive. What about you, Requiem? How have you managed to stay alive?
REQUIEM: I don't know. Some kind of inner strength, some energy pushes me on, but I can't describe it and I can't explain it. I hope to learn the truth one day.
C'RIZZ: I'm sorry, Requiem, I have to ask. Why did all this happen? Why so much death and destruction? Who allowed it to happen?
REQUIEM: Our government was weak, frightened. When the risk of an attack was imminent, it was we who struck first. Retaliation by other governments was immediate and total. Nothing could be done to prevent the complete destruction of Bortresoye. I remember the light, and then regaining consciousness to find the Archive as you see it now. Only much later did I venture to the surface and discover the terrible extent of our folly.
C'RIZZ: Your government's folly.
REQUIEM: We've always been at war, throughout history. Each successive government has tried to negotiate a lasting peace, only to end up causing another war. Little by little we have been brought to our knees.
C'RIZZ: When you say we, you mean the city.
REQUIEM: I mean Bortresoye. The whole world. The whole of Bortresoye has always been at war. Everyone. What surprises me is that we've lasted as long as we have, especially since natural resources were exhausted long ago, and we're the only species left on the planet.
C'RIZZ: You can't be. There must be thousands of different species. Millions. Well, everything from the smallest organism to the largest animal.
REQUIEM: All eradicated, C'Rizz, one after the other. Through excessive harvesting,
REQUIEM: through biological warfare, through scientific experimentation, the end result was the same. Extinction.
C'RIZZ: What was that?
REQUIEM: The world has become increasingly unstable, C'Rizz. By our actions, we've dealt it the final blow.
VOSS: Doctor, please tell us how you arrived on Bortresoye.
DOCTOR: That's a bit difficult, I'm afraid.
TRALFINIAL: Why?
DOCTOR: I don't know how we got here. I'm not privy to that information.
VOSS: Your mode of transport, what was it?
DOCTOR: We didn't have one.
CHARLEY: We just sort of arrived.
DOCTOR: Through the Interzone.
TRALFINIAL: Interzone?
DOCTOR: Yes, Interzone. I told you it would be difficult to explain.
VOSS: How were you expected to return to your own people?
CHARLEY: We weren't. And they're not our own people.
DOCTOR: There's no way back, you see. It's a one way ticket.
CHARLEY: Was that an earthquake, Doctor?
DOCTOR: Yes. And that's a little worrying when you're inside a concrete box a mile underground. Excuse me, Ministers, does that tend to happen regularly around here?
TRALFINIAL: There is some seismic activity, yes.
DOCTOR: I see. Look, I think we should be getting out of here. I'm sure I don't need to remind you that we're surrounded on all sides by millions of tons of shifting rock. Can't we discuss the Interzone at a later date?
TRALFINIAL: You're not going anywhere, Doctor.
VOSS: Least of all without us.
TRALFINIAL: Voss, are you mad, telling two strangers that you're looking to escape?
DOCTOR: Actually, he didn't exactly say that. He simply made it clear that we won't be allowed to leave this bunker unaccompanied.
TRALFINIAL: That's not how it sounded.
VOSS: Tralfinial, listen to me. There's a small possibility that the Doctor and his friend are telling the truth. They may have access to technology which is far more advanced than anything we have here. Isn't that worth investigating?
TRALFINIAL: I don't intend to abandon my people, Voss.
VOSS: What people? What people? There's no one left, apart from a handful of survivors on the surface who won't live long.
CHARLEY: What about everyone down here? What about your colleagues, your friends, your leader?
VOSS: I have no friends, My colleagues can take care of themselves. And as for our beloved leader

VOSS: No, don't you understand? It's finished. We have no future.
NURSE: Excelsior, please. My patients

DOCTOR: I beg your pardon?
EXCELSIOR: My victory gown. This is how the rest of our people will see me. It isn't finished yet, of course. There are a few little refinements to be added, but overall, what do you think? CHARLEY: Doctor, I can't see a thing. Prop me up a bit.
NURSE: That may not be wise. We don't want to risk damaging your spine even more.
CHARLEY: Please. I feel like a lemon just lying here.
NURSE: All right. Let me put a pillow behind your head. There. Better?
CHARLEY: Mmm. Much better, thanks.
EXCELSIOR: Well?

EXCELSIOR: You have good taste, young lady. What's your name?
CHARLEY: Charlotte.
EXCELSIOR: Charlotte.
CHARLEY: My friends call me Charley.
EXCELSIOR: And er, you are?
DOCTOR: Call me Doctor.
EXCELSIOR: Doctor. I, of course, need no introduction.
DOCTOR: Well, we are new here, so an introduction may be helpful.
NURSE: (nervous) The Doctor and Charley are still er, disorientated from their experiences, Excelsior.
EXCELSIOR: I see.
NURSE: It'll pass.
EXCELSIOR: I hope so. I am your leader!
DOCTOR: Leader?
EXCELSIOR: Excelsior. And please don't stand on ceremony. After all, you're the war heroes.
DOCTOR: Excelsior! Of course. Charley, didn't I say we could expect a visit from the leader?
CHARLEY: You did.
DOCTOR: Good for morale.
EXCELSIOR: It's unfortunate that you were injured, Charley.
CHARLEY: To say the least.
EXCELSIOR: Many have lost their lives.
DOCTOR: (sotto) To say the least.
EXCELSIOR: We owe them a great debt of gratitude in securing for us the freedoms that we too often take for granted. Their sacrifice makes it possible for the rest of us to lead our
EXCELSIOR: normal daily lives unhindered by the fear of oppression, or by the want of basic necessities. Thanks to those heroes, most of us still have our homes, our dignity, our pride. Were it not for their
DOCTOR: Excuse me, Excelsior, leader.
EXCELSIOR: Yes?
DOCTOR: When was this speech written?
EXCELSIOR: Speech? What speech?
DOCTOR: I'm starting to get the uncomfortable impression that it was a while ago. Possibly before the bomb dropped?
EXCELSIOR: Bomb? What bomb?
DOCTOR: Oh dear.
CHARLEY: You don't know? You must know.
EXCELSIOR: Know what?
DOCTOR: Life on the surface, or rather, the lack of it. What do you know about what's been happening above ground?
EXCELSIOR: My Ministers have kept me informed.

TRALFINIAL: Always.
EXCELSIOR: You see? I know all there is to know. Ministers, leave us. I wish to interview these two brave subjects alone.
TRALFINIAL: But surely
VOSS: Come, Tralfinial. Now!
